abstract.text: Initializes a statistics collection query to perform the specified calculations over a set of time intervals.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The type of sample to search for. This type must be an instance of the
class. You cannot perform statistics collection queries using other sample types.
A predicate that limits the results returned by the query. You can pass
if you want to perform the statistical calculation over all the samples of the specified type.
A list of options that define the type of statistical calculations performed and the way in which data from multiple sources are merged. For a list of valid options, see

The date used to anchor the collectionâ€™s time intervals. Use this parameter to set the start time for your time intervals. For example, if you are using a day interval, you might create a date object with a time of 2:00 a.m. This value sets the start of the day for each of your time intervals.

Technically, the anchor sets the start time for a single time interval. All other time intervals must align with this interval. The time intervals can extend before or after the anchor date. Each time interval has the same length, and there is no gap between adjacent intervals. Think of time as a number line: The anchor date represents its origin, with the intervals creating tick marks that extend away from the origin in both directions.
The date components that define the time interval for each statistics object in the collection. For a collection of sample time intervals, see
A newly initialized statistics collection query object.
After you instantiate the query, set up one or both of the callback handlers, and then call the
classâ€™s

method to run it. Queries run on an anonymous background queue. As soon as the query is complete, the initial results handler is executed on the same background queue (but not necessarily on the same thread). You typically dispatch these results to the main queue to update the user interface.

Statistics collection queries can also act as long-running queries. If you assign a statistics update handler, they continue to monitor the HealthKit store after gathering the initial results. The statistics update handler is called on the background queue every time a matching sample is saved to the HealthKit Store. You can cancel this query by calling the storeâ€™s
method.
Statistical calculations can take a considerable amount of time, especially if there are a large number of samples involved.

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the userâ€™s privacy and control.
The access point for all data managed by HealthKit.
A type that identifies samples that store numerical values.
A query that performs multiple statistics queries over a series of fixed-length time intervals.
The anchor date for the collectionâ€™s time intervals.
Initializes a statistics collection query to perform the specified calculations over a set of time intervals.
The results handler for the queryâ€™s initial results.
The date components that define the time interval for each statistics object in the collection.
A list of options that define the type of statistical calculations performed and the way in which data from multiple sources are merged.
The results handler for monitoring updates to the HealthKit store.
Options for specifying the statistic to calculate.
Calculate statistical data for graphs and charts.
A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A definition of logical conditions for constraining a search for a fetch or for in-memory filtering.
A date or time specified in terms of units (such as year, month, day, hour, and minute) to be evaluated in a calendar system and time zone.
A specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.

value.text: A representation of a specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
